head.title: New York Needs Its Consumer Affairs Agency

hedline.hl1: New York Needs Its Consumer Affairs Agency

block.p: It's ironic your Dec. 16 issue contained separate news articles of a New York City Consumer Affairs crackdown on businesses scalping tickets for Barney concerts and of Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani's considering abolishing the agency.

It's ironic your Dec. 16 issue contained separate news articles of a New York City Consumer Affairs crackdown on businesses scalping tickets for Barney concerts and of Mayor-elect Rudolph W. Giuliani's considering abolishing the agency.

Consumer Affairs was created 25 years ago to address the endless variety of New York City consumer fraud. Notwithstanding its sometimes overzealous pursuits, the department has consistently paid returns well beyond its small budget.

Its ability to focus attention on and take action against abuses like the resale of Barney tickets has a chilling effect on all those who would consider engaging in illegal trade practices. As a result, the city's retail environment is enhanced not only for consumers, residents and tourists alike, but for more ethical retailers.

The Mayor-elect may find suitable state agencies to discharge the de- partment's weights and measures and licensing functions, but no existing state agency can effectively perform as watchdog of the city's consumer marketplace. The city's economy will not be well served by a return to a caveat emptor philosophy of retailing that only a local consumer protection agency can guard against. WARREN W. TRAIGER New York, Dec. 16, 1993 The writer is a former New York City Consumer Affairs Dept. and State Consumer Protection Board official.
